repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Paraiba Rural Poverty
            Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Paraiba Rural
            Poverty Reduction Project for Brazil were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the Bank needs
            to be alert to the potentially de-mobilizing impacts of
            prolonged delay between operations and disruptive changes in
            leadership and staffing, especially technical. Cooperar is
            an experienced and committed project unit which needs
            specific forms of institutional support to enable it to
            perform to potential. The institutionalization of monitoring
            and evaluation (M and E) is essential and successive
            projects should update and reinforce M and E capacity and
            utilization. The community-driven development (CDD)
            methodology remains a cost-effective avenue to basic social
            infrastructure acquisition and to social capital formation
            but more systematic employment and income generation
            requires significant changes. Productive activities in
            semi-arid zones with water difficulties are increasingly
            unsustainable. Rural water supply requires an institutional
            intervention to help sustain the physical intervention.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Paraiba Rural Poverty
            Reduction Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Second
            Paraiba Rural Poverty Reduction Project for Brazil is to
            support the Government of Paraiba's efforts to reduce
            the incidence of rural poverty by: (a) improving access to
            small-scale socioeconomic infrastructure and services; (b)
            raising incomes and capital assets through investments in
            productive activities while facilitating linkages between
            small producers and national and international markets; and
            (c) strengthening the capacity of Municipal Councils (MCs)
            and Community Associations (CAs) to raise funding and
            harmonize policies and institutional arrangements for
            delivery of public investments intended to benefit the rural
            poor. The change will, at the Borrower's request and in
            fulfillment of the project development objective, extend the
            closing date of loan 7628-BR to February 28, 2014. This will
            be the first extension of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Paraiba Rural Poverty
            Reduction Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Second
            Paraiba Rural Poverty Reduction Project for Brazil is to
            support the Government of Paraiba's efforts to reduce
            the incidence of rural poverty by: (a) improving access to
            small-scale socioeconomic infrastructure and services; (b)
            raising incomes and capital assets through investments in
            productive activities while facilitating linkages between
            small producers and national and international markets; and
            (c) strengthening the capacity of Municipal Councils (MCs)
            and Community Associations (CAs) to raise funding and
            harmonize policies and institutional arrangements for
            delivery of public investments intended to benefit the rural
            poor. The project PDO and Implementation Progress (IP) are
            moderately satisfactory. To date, 400 community subprojects
            have been approved for financing and implementation,
            benefiting some 24,000 rural families. The rating for
            financial management is moderately satisfactory and all
            other fiduciary ratings (i.e., social and environmental
            safeguards, procurement) are rated satisfactory. The
            reallocation responds to the borrower's request,
            approved by the Guarantor's Ministry of Planning
            through its Commission for External Finance (COFIEX) on
            August 8, 2012 and received by the Bank on September 4,
            2012, to absorb unallocated loan proceeds to finance
            community subjects and administrative costs, in attainment
            of the PDO.
